title: Cardiff University students can now opt for LGBT+ only accommodation
text:
Cardiff University students are now living in LGBT+ only accommodation (Picture: Getty Images)

Cardiff has become the first university in Wales to offer LGBT+ accommodation to students.

First years at the institution have backed the move, which aims to help freshers ‘adjust to university life’.

Other UK universities offering similar schemes for the LGBT+ community include Birmingham, Sheffield and the University of the West of England, Bristol.

First year Cardiff student Aimee, who now lives in one of the flats, told student news site The Cardiff Tab that she felt safer living there because ‘you know you aren’t living with other people who are homophobic’.

She added that it meant she was ‘able to meet other [LGBT+] people without having to go to socials with the LGBT society’.

Cardiff is one of a number of univerisities around the country to offer schemes of this nature (Picture: Getty Images)

According to the Cardiff University website, ‘some flats at Talybont North and South have been reserved for LGBT+ students and allies’.

It said that following student feedback, the accommodation is being ‘offered as an option for students who would prefer to live with, or feel most supported living with, other LGBT+ students and/or allies.’

Students can select the option when they apply for housing online.

A Cardiff University spokesperson told the Tab: ‘Adjusting to university life can prove to be a difficult and stressful time in a period of transition and change.

‘We took the decision to pilot LGBT+ accommodation for the 2019/2020 year as part of a wider package of measures to help LGBT+ students adjust to university life.

‘The University recognises that the accommodation will not be for everyone.

‘We feel it’s important that students have the choice of living in LGBT+ only accommodation if they wish, just the same as we offer students the option to live in primarily Welsh speaking shared accommodation, or opt to live in single sex housing.’

However, when Sheffield University began offering similar housing options last year, some warned that it could pave the wave to ‘segregation’ on campus.

Simon Thompson, director of housing service Accommodation for Students, told The Telegraph: ‘University is about opening your horizons and meeting people from different cultures, different backgrounds, different sexualities, everything.

‘I think it’s a disadvantage if people close themselves off and don’t socialise with straight people. It just seems madness to me.’

Accommodation for various other communities are offered by universities nationwide.
